lesson.name: Lesson 2.14: Solving Problems with Systems of Linear Inequalities in Two Variables

page.title: 2.14.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will take a closer look at whether points on the boundary lines of the system’s solution region are included in the solutions. Analyzing graphs and communicating observations about them will require your attention to precision. You will also apply your insights to solve more challenging contextual problems. 

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain how to tell if a point on the boundary of the graph of the solutions to a system of inequalities is a solution.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 2.14.1: Analyzing Graphs that Represent Linear Equations and Inequalities
  • 2.14.2: Determining if Points on Boundary Lines Are Solutions to a System
  • 2.14.2: Self Check
  • 2.14.3: Solving Problems to Satisfy Multiple Constraints Simultaneously
  • 2.14.3: Self Check
  • 2.14.4: Identifying Graph Regions Included in a System’s Solution

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 2.14.5: Practice
  • 2.14.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 2.14.1: Analyzing Graphs that Represent Linear Equations and Inequalities
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Which one doesn’t belong?

 

A.

B.

C.

D.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  • A is the only set of graphs that represents a system of equations. It is the only system with exactly one solution. 
  • B is the only set of graphs that represents a system of inequalities with no solutions. 
  • C is the only set of graphs in which the boundaries are horizontal and vertical lines. It is the only one representing a system with an infinite number of solutions. 
  • D is the only graph that does not represent a system. It only represents one inequality.

page.title: 2.14.2: Determining if Points on Boundary Lines Are Solutions to a System
page.contents:
Activity

Here are the graphs of the inequalities in this system:

{x<yy≥-2x−6 { x < y y ≥ - 2 x − 6

Decide whether each point is a solution to the system. Be prepared to explain how you know.

  1. \((3,-5)\)
Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No. \((3,-5)\) is in the shaded region containing the solutions to one of the inequalities but not in the region where the shading overlaps.



  1. \((0,5)\)
Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes. \((0,5)\) is in the region where the solutions to the two inequalities overlap.



  1. \((-6,6)\)
Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes. (\(-6,6)\) is on the solid boundary of \(y\geq-2x-6\) because \(0=-2(-3)−6\), and it is within the shaded region representing solutions to \(x<y\).



  1. \((3,3)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No. While \((3,3)\) is clearly a solution to \(y\geq-2x-6\), it is on the dashed boundary of \(x < y\). The statement \(3<3\) is not true.




  1. \((-2,-2)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, because \(-2<-2\) is not true. Even though it is on the solid boundary of one, it is on the dashed boundary of the other.




Video:

Watch the following video to learn more



Extending Your Thinking

Find a system of inequalities with this triangle as its set of solutions:

Enter your answer here:

\(x+y\geq2\), \(x+4y\leq14\), \(4x+y\leq11\) or equivalent

page.title: 2.14.2: Self Check
page.contents:
Here is the graph of this system of inequalities. Which of the following ordered pairs falls within the solution set?


\(6x\;+\;4y\;\leq\;34\)

\(-2x\;+\;7y\;>\;22\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair falls on both boundary lines, but it only satisfies the first inequality. The answer is \((2, 4)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair falls on a boundary line and satisfies the first inequality but not the second one. The answer is \((2, 4)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair falls on a dashed boundary line, and it does not satisfy either inequality. The correct answer is \((2, 4)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: This ordered pair is a solution to both inequalities and falls within the solution region on the graph. This is the correct answer.

page.title: 2.14.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Determine Solutions of Systems of Inequalities on Boundary Lines

A solution to a system of inequalities only exists on a boundary line if the line is solid, not dashed.

Example

Solve the system by graphing: 

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}x-y>3\\y<-\frac15x+4.\end{array}\right.\)

Solution

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}x-y>3\\y<-\frac15x+4\end{array}\right.\)

Graph \(x − y > 3\), by graphing \(x − y = 3\) and testing a point.


The intercepts are \(x = 3\) and \(y = −3\), and the boundary line will be dashed.


Test \((0, 0)\), which makes the inequality false, so shade (red) the side that does not contain \((0, 0)\).

Graph \(y<-\frac15x+4\) by graphing \(y=-\frac15x+4\) using the slope \(m=-15\) and \(y\)-intercept \(b = 4\). The boundary line will be dashed.

Test \((0, 0)\), which makes the inequality true, so shade (blue) the side that contains \((0, 0)\).

Choose a test point in the solution and verify that it is a solution to both inequalities.

The point of intersection of the two lines is not included because both boundary lines were dashed. The solution is the area shaded twice—which appears as the darkest shaded region.

Notice that the point \((0,-3)\) is NOT a solution because it falls on the red dashed line.
The point \((4, -2)\) IS a solution because it is included in the solutions to both inequalities.

Try It: Determine Solutions of Systems of Inequalities on Boundary Lines


Which of the following are solutions of the graph below?

  1. \((2,1)\)
  2. \((2,3)\)
  3. \((5,0)\)
  4. \((3,-1)\)
  5. \((-1,6)\)
  6. \((1, 6)\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to determine if the coordinates are solutions:

Remember that when a coordinate is on a boundary line, it must be solid if it is a solution. The coordinate must also be in the overlapping shaded regions to be a solution to the entire system.

The answers are A and D.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.14.3: Solving Problems to Satisfy Multiple Constraints Simultaneously
page.contents:
Activity

Your teacher will give you either a problem card or a data card. Do not show or read your card to your partner.

If your teacher gives you the data card:

  1. Silently read the information on your card.
  2. Ask your partner, “What specific information do you need?” and wait for your partner to ask for information. Only give information that is on your card. (Do not figure out anything for your partner!)
  3. Before telling your partner the information, ask, “Why do you need to know (that piece of information)?”
  4. Read the problem card and solve the problem independently.
  5. Share the data card and discuss your reasoning.

If your teacher gives you the problem card:

  1. Silently read your card and think about what information you need to answer the question.
  2. Ask your partner for the specific information that you need.
  3. Explain to your partner how you are using the information to solve the problem.
  4. When you have enough information, share the problem card with your partner, and solve the problem independently.
  5. Read the data card and discuss your reasoning.

Pause here so your teacher can review your work. Ask your teacher for a new set of cards and repeat the activity, trading roles with your partner.




Enter your answers here:

Card 1:

  1. No. The combination meets the rule about the total number of members, but does not meet the rule about the number of adults compared to the number of students. Sample reasoning:

  • The point (8,6) is not in the shaded region of the graph representing the rule about children-to-adult ratio.

  • If 6 is substituted into the inequality representing the rule about children-to-adult ratio and then evaluated, the inequality, 6 ≤ 12(8), is a false statement.

  • The maximum number of adults is 5.

    •  

    Card 2:

    1. Each team can have at least 8 people: 6 children and 2 adults. Sample reasoning: The region where all three graphs overlap represent combinations that meet all three rules. The lowest numbers of children and adults in the region are 6 and 2.

    2. The maximum number of adults on a team is 5.

page.title: 2.14.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Which of the following ordered pairs falls within the solution set to the system of inequalities?

\(–5x\;+\;2y\;>\;–5\)

\(4x\;+\;3y\;<\;27\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair falls on both boundary lines and does not satisfy either inequality. The answer is \((2, 5)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair does not satisfy both inequalities. The answer is \((2, 5)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: This ordered pair falls within the region representing the solution set.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair does not satisfy both inequalities. The answer is \((2, 5)\).

page.title: 2.14.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solve Applications of Systems of Inequalities

When we use variables other than \(x\) and \(y\) to define an unknown quantity, we must change the names of the axes of the graph as well.

Example: Omar needs to eat at least 800 calories before going to his team practice. All he wants is hamburgers, \(h\), and cookies, \(c\), and he doesn’t want to spend more than $5. At the hamburger restaurant near his college, each hamburger has 240 calories and costs $1.40. Each cookie has 160 calories and costs $0.50.

  1. Write a system of inequalities to model this situation.
  2. Graph the system.
  3. Could he eat 3 hamburgers and 1 cookie?
  4. Could he eat 2 hamburgers and 4 cookies?

Solution

a.)

Let \(h=\) the number of hamburgers and \(c=\) the number of cookies.
To find the system of equations, translate the information.
The calories from hamburgers at 240 calories each, plus the calories from cookies at 160 calories each
must be at least 800.
\(240h+160c\geq800\)
The amount spent on hamburgers at $1.40 each, plus the amount spent on cookies at $0.50 each
must be no more than $5.00. 
\(1.40h+0.50c\leq5\)
The number of hamburgers must be greater than or equal to 0.
\(h\geq0\)
The number of cookies must be greater than or equal to 0.
\(c\geq0\)
We have our system of equations. \(\left\{\begin{array}{l}240h\;+\;160c\;\geq\;800\\1.40h\;+0.50c\;\leq\;5\\h\;\geq\;0\\c\;\geq\;0\end{array}\right.\)


b.)
Since \(h\geq0\)   and \(c\geq0\)   (both are greater than or equal to zero), all solutions will be in the first quadrant. As a result, our graph shows only quadrant one.

To graph \(240h+160c\geq80\) , graph \(240h+160c=800\) as a solid line.
Choose \((0, 0)\) as a test point. Since it does not make the inequality true, shade (red) the side that does not include the point \((0, 0)\).

Graph \(1.40h+0.50c\leq5\) . The boundary line is \(1.40h+0.50c=5\) . We test \((0, 0)\), and it makes the inequality true. We shade the side of the line that includes \((0, 0)\).

The solution of the system is the region of the graph that is shaded the darkest. The boundary line sections that border the darkly shaded section are included in the solution, as are the points on the \(x\)-axis from \((5, 0)\) to \((10, 0)\).

c.) To determine if 3 hamburgers and 1 cookie would meet Omar’s criteria, we see if the point \((3, 2)\) is in the solution region. It is, so Omar might choose to eat 3 hamburgers and 1 cookie.

d.) To determine if 2 hamburgers and 4 cookies would meet Omar’s criteria, we see if the point \((2, 4)\) is in the solution region. It is, so Omar might choose to eat 2 hamburgers and 4 cookies.

We could also test the possible solutions by substituting the values into each inequality.


Try It: Solve Applications of Systems of Inequalities

  1. Philip’s doctor tells him he should add at least 1,000 more calories per day to his usual diet. Philip wants to buy protein bars, \(p\), that cost $1.80 each and have 140 calories and juice, \(j\), that costs $1.25 per bottle and has 125 calories. He doesn’t want to spend more than $12.
    1. Write a system of inequalities that models this situation.
    2. Graph the system.
    3. Can he buy 3 protein bars and 5 bottles of juice?
    4. Can he buy 5 protein bars and 3 bottles of juice?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to write and graph this system of inequalities to find solutions:

  1. \(\left\{\begin{array}{l}140p+125j\geq1000\\1.80p+1.25j\leq12\end{array}\right.\)

  3. yes
  4. no

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.14.4: Identifying Graph Regions Included in a System’s Solution
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

A factory produces “widgets” and “zurls.” The combined number of widgets and zurls made each day cannot be more than 12. The maximum number of widgets the factory can produce in a day is 4.

Let \(x\) be the number of widgets and \(y\) be the number of zurls.

  1. Select all the inequalities that represent this situation.
    1. \(x<4\)
    2. \(x\leq4\)
    3. \(x>4\)
    4. \(x+y>12\)
    5. \(x+y\leq12\)

Enter your answer here:

\(x\leq4\) and \(x+y\leq12\)

  1. Here are graphs of \(x=4\) and \(x+y=12\).
    Complete the graphs (by shading regions and adjusting line types as needed) to show all the allowable numbers of widgets and zurls that the factory can produce in one day.

Enter your answer here:


See graph.



  1. Does each ordered pair represent an allowable combination of widgets and zurls produced in one day?
    \((4,5)\)
    \((11,1)\)
    \((4,12)\)
    \((3,9)\)

Enter your answer here:

Yes, no, no, yes

page.title: 2.14.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For 1-2, use this situation:

Jada has p pennies and n nickels that add up to more than 40 cents. She has fewer than 20 coins altogether.

1. Which two inequalities could make up a system of inequalities that represents how many pennies and nickels that Jada could have? Select all that apply.

Correct! \(p+n<20\), \(0.01p + 0.05n >0.40\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are \(p+n<20\), \(0.01p + 0.05n >0.40\), \({p+n<20, 0.01p + 0.05n >0.40}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. Is it possible that Jada has each of the following combinations of coins? If so, explain or show how you know. If not, state which constraint—the amount of money or the number of coins—it does not meet.
  a. 15 pennies and 5 nickels

Correct! She has fewer than 20 coins. 15+5=20, it is not less than 20

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is No. She has fewer than 20 coins.15+5=20, it is not less than 20. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  b. 16 pennies and 2 nickels

Correct! She has more than 40 cents.16+2(5)=26, it is not more than 40 cents.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is No. She has more than 40 cents. 16+2(5)=26, it is not more than 40 cents. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  c. 10 pennies and 8 nickels

Correct! She has less than 20 coins. 10 +8=18. That is less than 20 coins. She has more than 40 cents. 10+8(5)=50, which is more than 40 cents.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. She has less than 20 coins. 10+8=18. That is less than 20 coins. She has more than 40 cents. 10+8(5)=50, which is more than 40 cents. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


3. A triathlon athlete swims at an average rate of 2.4 miles per hour, and bikes at an average rate of 16.1 miles per hour. At the end of one training session, she has swam and biked more than 20 miles in total.

The inequality 2.4s+16.1b>20 and this graph represent the relationship between the hours of swimming, s, the hours of biking, h, and the total distance the athlete could have traveled in miles.

Mai said, "I'm not sure the graph is right. For example, the point (10,3) is in the shaded region, but it's not realistic for an athlete to swim for 10 hours and bike for 3 hours in a training session! I think triathlon athletes generally train for no more than 2 hours a day."

Which inequality represents Mai's last statement?

Correct! \(s+b≤2\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.14.3 and 2.14.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(s+b≤2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


4. Elena is considering buying bracelets and necklaces as gifts for her friends. Bracelets, b,  cost $3, and necklaces, n, cost $5. She can spend no more than $30 on the gifts. Elena needs at least 7 gift items.

This graph represents the inequality 3b+5n≤30, which describes the cost constraint in this situation.

Let b represent the number of bracelets and n the number of necklaces.

   a. Which inequality represents the number of gift items that Elena needs?

Correct! \(b+n≥7\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 2.14.3 and 2.14.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is b+n≥7.You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  b. Which of the following could be solutions to the system of inequalities? Select all that apply.

Correct! (7,1), (6,2)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 2.14.3 and 2.14.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are (7,1), (6,2). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. A gardener is buying some topsoil and compost to fill his garden. His budget is $70. Topsoil costs $1.89 per cubic foot, and compost costs $4.59 per cubic foot.

Select all statements or representations that correctly describe the gardener's constraints in this situation. Let t represent the cubic feet of topsoil and c the cubic feet of compost.

A:

The combination of 7.5 cubic feet of topsoil and 12 cubic feet of compost is within the gardener's budget.

B:

If the line on the graph represents the equation \(1.89t+4.59c=70\), this graph represents the solutions to the gardener's budget constraint.

C:

\(1.89t+4.59c≥70 \)

D:

The combination of 5 cubic feet of topsoil and 20 cubic feet of compost is within the gardener's budget.

E:

\(1.89t+4.59c≤70\)

F:

If the line on the graph represents the equation \(1.89t+4.59c=70\), this graph represents the solutions to the gardener's budget constraint.

Correct! The combination of 7.5 cubic feet of topsoil and 12 cubic feet of compost is within the gardener's budget., \(1.89t+4.59c≤70\), If the line on the graph represents the equation \(1.89t+4.59c=70\), this graph represents the solutions to the gardener's budget constraint.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.14.3 and 2.14.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are: The combination of 7.5 cubic feet of topsoil and 12 cubic feet of compost is within the gardener's budget., \(1.89t+4.59c≤70\), If the line on the graph represents the equation \(1.89t+4.59c=70\), this graph represents the solutions to the gardener's budget constraint. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 2.14.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain how to tell if a point on the boundary of the graph of the solutions to a system of inequalities is a solution.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 2.14.1: Analyzing Graphs that Represent Linear Equations and Inequalities

    • In this activity, you carefully analyzed and compared graphs that represent linear equations and inequalities. Making comparisons prompted you to think about the solutions to the equations, inequalities, or systems that were represented. It also gave you an opportunity to use language precisely.
  • 2.14.2: Determining if Points on Boundary Lines Are Solutions to a System
    • In this activity, you took a closer look at whether points that are on the boundary lines are solutions to the system.
  • 2.14.2: Self Check
  • 2.14.3: Solving Problems to Satisfy Multiple Constraints Simultaneously
    • In this activity, you had an opportunity to use your understanding of systems of linear inequalities to solve problems that involve satisfying multiple constraints simultaneously.
  • 2.14.3: Self Check
  • 2.14.4: Identifying Graph Regions Included in a System’s Solution
    • In this activity, you determined all the inequalities that represent a given situation and shaded regions and adjusted line types to represent solutions. 

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 2.14.5: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
